Yannas addresses joint legal vs. physical custody definitions, the ‘real advantage’ standard for removal, and best-interests analysis, but it does not impose or discuss specific obligations to cooperate on school-related issues or to keep each other informed about education. Thus it does not substantively support that particular proposition, beyond the general best-interests framework.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The judge did award joint or shared legal custody, which G. *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The Judgment also requires the parties to cooperate on school-related matters, to keep each other reasonably informed regarding the child’s education, and to act in the child’s best interests consistent with Massachusetts law, including M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and applicable case law such as *Yannas v. Although the court repeatedly applies a “best interests of the child” standard, it does so in the specific context of a removal request and not in articulating the statutory standard for modifying custody or parenting-time provisions based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: When the mother informed the father of her intention to move to New Hampshire, the father refused to consent to removal of the children from the Commonwealth and filed a complaint for modification of the divorce decree in the Probate and Family Court seeking, among other things, sole physical custody and a temporary order enjoining the mother from removing the children from the Commonwealth. The mother counterclaimed for modification granting her sole physical custody and for a temporary order permitting the planned relocation to Bristol, New Hampshire.

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: This Complaint for Modification is brought pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 (and, to the extent applicable, M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20), which authorize the Court to modify custody and parenting-time provisions of an existing judgment upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The case is a complaint for modification of alimony and child support brought under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 37; it does not involve modification of custody or parenting time. While it states the standard for modifying child support (change in circumstances and needs/benefit of the children), it does not address custody/parenting-time determinations or cite G.L. c. 209C, § 20. Thus, it is not proper authority for the specific proposition about modifying custody and parenting-time provisions under those statutes.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1976, c. 279, § 1. … A substantial and permanent decrease in the income of the support provider is one of the material circumstances to be considered in a request for reduction of a support award.”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: These actions by Father—keeping Emily home from school without proper justification and failing to bring her to tutoring—are inconsistent with the Judgment’s requirement that the parties cooperate regarding the child’s education and make joint legal-custody decisions in the child’s best interests. See *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (conflict in joint legal custody and failure to cooperate may warrant modification); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981) (best interests includes promoting education and emotional welfare).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss joint legal custody, parental cooperation, or modification based on conflicts between joint custodians. It focuses instead on the general principle that custody determinations must be based on the child’s welfare and that custody cannot be used to punish a parent for misconduct. While it emphasizes the “best interests” standard, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that conflict in joint legal custody or failure to cooperate about education may warrant modification.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.… The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: These actions by Father—keeping Emily home from school without proper justification and failing to bring her to tutoring—are inconsistent with the Judgment’s requirement that the parties cooperate regarding the child’s education and make joint legal-custody decisions in the child’s best interests. *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Rolde for the idea that the "best interests" standard specifically includes promoting education and emotional welfare. Rolde does discuss the best-interests standard in custody determinations and references the children’s welfare and development, but it does not single out education or emotional welfare as distinct components or elaborate on them in the way the proposition suggests. The case is about whether joint vs. sole custody is appropriate in light of parental conflict, not about cooperation in educational decisions or school attendance.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … The judge found the wife has been the “primary nurturing parent” and “primary caretaker” and that the children have the “strongest bond” with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.

*Macaulay v. Macaulay*, 19 Mass. *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Father’s conduct demonstrates an ongoing inability or refusal to prioritize Emily’s educational needs and to comply with the spirit and letter of joint legal custody, which requires meaningful, cooperative decision-making and consistent support for the child’s schooling. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003) (stability and cooperation are critical in custody arrangements); *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss a parent’s failure to prioritize a child’s educational needs or noncompliance with joint legal custody orders, so it does not directly support that factual aspect of the proposition. However, it clearly affirms the broader legal principle that in custody determinations stability, continuity, and the parents’ ability (or inability) to communicate and make shared decisions are critical considerations. It is therefore an accurate citation for the general point that stability and cooperation are central to custody arrangements, but not for the more specific claim about a father’s educational neglect or refusal to honor joint legal custody.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The parties do not contest the judge’s conclusion that joint legal custody was not appropriate in light of the past inability of the parents to communicate productively about and jointly work together in making major decisions concerning Kali’s well being…. The statute gives direction to the judge’s consideration of a child’s ‘best interests’ by ‘evincing a general intent on the part of the Legislature to maintain the bonds between the child and her caregiver.’… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.proposition: Father’s conduct demonstrates an ongoing inability or refusal to prioritize Emily’s educational needs and to comply with the spirit and letter of joint legal custody, which requires meaningful, cooperative decision-making and consistent support for the child’s schooling. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003) (stability and cooperation are critical in custody arrangements); *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss joint legal custody, cooperative decision-making between parents, or parental support for a child’s schooling in the sense invoked by the proposition. Instead, it addresses standards for removing a child from a natural parent in a care and protection/guardianship context, focusing on parental unfitness and improper reliance on lifestyle judgments. It provides general principles about parental rights and state intervention but does not establish or apply any rule about the obligations inherent in joint legal custody arrangements or prioritizing educational needs as framed in the proposition.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.relevant_excerpt: “Custody is not to be transferred from the natural parent simply because another prospective custodian is thought to be better qualified. A comparison of the advantage the prospective custodian may offer to the child with those that may be offered by the natural parents is inappropriate. … ‘State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.’ … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’”

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.proposition: Father’s pattern of behavior has created substantial conflict around basic educational decisions, including school attendance and participation in remedial services, rendering the current joint legal custody arrangement unworkable as to educational issues. See *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976); *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010) (courts may modify legal custody to resolve ongoing decision-making impasses affecting the child).
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.support_reasoning: Vilakazi v. Maxie is a straight custody/visitation dispute in which the court affirms an award of sole custody to the father and elimination of visitation for the mother based on the child’s welfare. The opinion does not involve joint legal custody, parental decision‑making impasses, or modification of legal custody limited to educational (or other discrete) issues. It therefore does not provide authority for the proposition that a pattern of conflict around educational decisions renders joint legal custody unworkable or that courts may modify only legal custody to resolve such impasses.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.relevant_excerpt: “The material facts found and reported by the judge support his action in awarding custody of the child to the father and stepmother with no rights of visitation by the mother. In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child.’ … We hold that the judge correctly applied these principles in deciding this case and that on the facts found and reported by him he did not abuse his discretion.”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: Father’s pattern of behavior has created substantial conflict around basic educational decisions, including school attendance and participation in remedial services, rendering the current joint legal custody arrangement unworkable as to educational issues. *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: Smith v. McDonald is a paternity/relocation case focused on statutory interpretation of G.L. c. 209C and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a custodial mother to return to Massachusetts. It does not address joint legal custody, decision‑making impasses between parents, or modification of legal custody (educational or otherwise). Citing it for the proposition that courts may modify legal custody to resolve ongoing decision‑making conflicts is therefore inaccurate and not supported by the opinion’s holding or reasoning.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: "The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. ... As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is 'free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].' ... The paternity statute further provides that 'the mother shall continue to have custody after an adjudication of paternity or voluntary acknowledgment of parentage' (emphasis added) unless and until a court orders otherwise. G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (b)."

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related case law, including *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), and *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998), as well as *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time modification is the best interests of the child.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the decision in terms of determining which placement is in the child’s best interests, treating that as the controlling standard once parental unfitness is found. It expressly cites G.L. c. 210, § 3(c) and prior custody/adoption cases and describes “best interests of the child” as the central and discretionary question in custody/adoption determinations. Although this case arises under c. 119 and c. 210 rather than c. 208, it clearly supports the general proposition that the paramount consideration in custody/placement decisions is the child’s best interests.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … [I]n child custody cases the best interests standard mandated by G. L. c. 210, § 3, is ‘a flexible one.’”
